channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: C.I.A. Judgment on Russia Built on Swell of Evidence
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin last month at the Kremlin. The C.I.A. believes he deployed computer hackers with the goal of tipping the election to Donald J. Trump.
item.description: The conclusion that Russia intervened in the election to help Donald J. Trump was based on what many believe is overwhelming circumstantial evidence, which is often the most intelligence analysts have at their disposal.
item.dc:creator: MARK MAZZETTI and ERIC LICHTBLAU

item.title: Kurdish Militant Group Claims Responsibility for Deadly Istanbul Bombing
item.media:description: Coffins of police officers were carried on Sunday in Istanbul.
item.description: The Kurdistan Freedom Falcons said in a statement on Sunday that it had carried out the double suicide bombing in Turkey the night before that killed dozens and targeted the police.
item.dc:creator: SAFAK TIMUR

item.title: A President Trump Excites, and Worries, Persian Gulf Leaders
item.description: The leaders wonder if President Trump will support Syrian rebels, get tougher with Iran, or increase the American military’s presence in the region.
item.dc:creator: ERIC SCHMITT
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: For Women Under ISIS, a Tyranny of Dress Code and Punishment
item.media:description: Women waited for aid to be distributed in Mosul, Iraq, on Dec. 4. Even before the Islamic State took control, Mosul was a conservative city where most women covered their hair with a scarf and their arms with long sleeves.
item.description: Escapees from the Iraqi city of Mosul describe the Islamic State’s extreme dress code, which made showing so much as an eyebrow an offense punishable by the whip.
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Cathedral Bombing in Cairo Leaves Egypt Alarmed, and Its President Scrambling
item.media:description: The body of a Christian woman killed in a bombing at a cathedral on Sunday was carried to a cemetery in Cairo on Monday. The attack was the deadliest in years against Egyptian Christians.
item.description: President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi moved to reassure Egypt’s Coptic Christians after a bombing at their cathedral in Cairo stirred fears of resurgent Islamist violence.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH
item.category: St Mark's Coptic Orthodox Cathedral (Cairo, Egypt)

item.title: With Success Comes Dissension in Italy’s Five Star Movement
item.media:description: Beppe Grillo, the leader of the populist Five Star Movement, delivering a speech in Turin, Italy, before a referendum that led to the resignation of Prime Minister Matteo Renzi.
item.description: As an anti-establishment party gains in popularity, some members worry that it may be drifting away from its founding ethos and toward one of centralized power.
item.dc:creator: JASON HOROWITZ

item.title: Center-Left Party Poised to Regain Power in Romania
item.media:description: A woman cast her ballot as another voter exited the booth and an election official, right, looked on at a polling station in Sintesti, near Bucharest, Romania, on Sunday.
item.description: Despite recent scandals, the Social Democratic Party secured a large lead in parliamentary elections. The main question now is who will be prime minister.
item.dc:creator: KIT GILLET

item.title: Paolo Gentiloni, Italy’s Foreign Minister, Will Try to Form a New Government
item.description: Mr. Gentiloni hopes to lead Italy out of a political crisis that ensued with the recent resignation of Matteo Renzi as prime minister.
item.dc:creator: GAIA PIANIGIANI

item.title: Venezuela’s Government Plays Santa, After Seizing Millions of Toys
item.description: A toy distributor is accused of hoarding and price gouging, and the consumer protection agency steps in. But some accuse the government of grandstanding.
item.dc:creator: PATRICIA TORRES and NICHOLAS CASEY

item.title: Nelson Journal: With Flood of Urbanites, a Canadian Hippie Haven Tries to Keep Its Mellow
item.media:description: A late-night busker playing in Nelson, British Columbia. The recent influx of people to this compact town of 10,000 has led to an affordable housing crisis.
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: Nelson, British Columbia, has everything laid-back urban refugees priced out of other cities could want. Except housing.
item.dc:creator: DAN LEVIN

item.title: Niger Feels Ripple Effect of Boko Haram as Fears of Food Shortage Spread
item.description: The militants — who have stolen cattle, raided markets and uprooted farmers — have created a malnutrition crisis in Nigeria that could spill across borders.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY

item.title: Philippines President Criticizes Times Coverage of Deadly Antidrug Campaign
item.media:description: The body of a man killed by unknown gunmen lay behind a convenience store in Manila.
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.description: The office of the president, Rodrigo Duterte, said the article and photographic essay had falsely depicted the Philippines as “the Wild, Wild West.”
item.dc:creator: RICHARD C. PADDOCK

item.title: If Donald Trump Pushes on Taiwan, How China Could Push Back
item.media:description: President-elect Donald J. Trump being interviewed by Chris Wallace of “Fox News Sunday” at Trump Tower in New York on Saturday.
item.description: The president-elect has suggested that the “One China” policy could be used as a bargaining chip, but China has some leverage of its own.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ

item.title: What in the World: If the Pool Is Warm in Paris, Thank the Washing Machine
item.media:credit: Illustration by Tamara Shopsin; Photos by All for You, Mrnok, via shutterstock
item.description: The city has developed clever ways to reuse excess heat from unconventional sources like household wastewater.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN

item.title: António Guterres, Sworn In as U.N.’s Next Leader, Must Factor Trump Into His Plans
item.description: Donald J. Trump’s election will affect major issues facing António Guterres, including the Syrian war and how to preserve the United Nations’ funding and values.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Rex Tillerson’s Company, Exxon, Has Billions at Stake Over Russia Sanctions
item.media:description: Rex W. Tillerson of Exxon Mobil has voiced skepticism about sanctions that halted some Exxon Mobil projects in Russia.
item.media:credit: Ben Torres for The New York Times
item.description: Russia’s energy industry could create a blurry line between Mr. Tillerson’s interests as an oilman and his new job if he becomes America’s leading diplomat.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER and CLIFFORD KRAUSS

item.title: A. A. Gill, Who Gleefully Skewered Britain’s Restaurants, Dies at 62
item.media:description: A. A. Gill in 2003. He died of lung cancer, which he described as “a trucker’s gut-buster, gimpy, malevolent, meaty malignancy.”
item.description: As an essayist and cultural critic for The Sunday Times, Mr. Gill laid stylishly malicious waste to superstar chefs, trendy restaurants and food fads.
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM GRIMES

item.title: Macedonia's Nationalists Win Election: Official Results
item.description: Veteran leader Nikola Gruevski's nationalist VMRO-DPMNE won 51 out of 120 seats in Macedonia's parliament in a snap poll on Sunday that is expected to end a two-year long crisis.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: The Interpreter: Russia and the U.S. Election: What We Know and Don’t Know
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, right, has been praised by Donald J. Trump, who has repeatedly promised to realign the United States with Russia.
item.description: A guide to separating fact from rumor and speculation in a swirl of news about Russia’s electoral interference.
item.dc:creator: MAX FISHER

item.title: Indian Police Arrest Moviegoer for Failing to Rise for Anthem
item.media:description: Moviegoers in New Delhi stood for the national anthem before a screening Dec. 4. A Supreme Court ruling requires movie theater patrons to stand respectfully while the anthem is played, unless they are physically unable.
item.description: The episode follows a Supreme Court order last month that the anthem be played before each showing, and that everyone in attendance must stand.
item.dc:creator: HARI KUMAR

item.title: Syrian Government Moves Closer to Completely Controlling Aleppo
item.media:description: Fighters of the Free Syrian Army fired an anti-aircraft weapon in the rebel-held Mashhad area in southeastern Aleppo on Monday as they battled Syrian government forces.
item.description: Government forces and their allies have squeezed fighters and civilians in rebel-held parts of the city into a sliver of territory, spokesmen said.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD

item.title: Global Health: British Officials Issue a Report Card on Aid Organizations
item.media:description: A toddler received a vaccination in Haiti in 2010.
item.description: The report praised three well-known nonprofits, but took aim at Unesco’s “weak” organizational strength.
item.dc:creator: DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.
item.category: Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria
United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization

item.title: Hunt for Missing Marcos Art Seeks to Regain Momentum
item.media:description: Imelda Marcos, shown in her apartment in Manila in 2014, and her husband, Ferdinand E. Marcos, who died in 1989, amassed an art collection possibly worth hundreds of millions of dollars.
item.description: The ouster of the Philippine leader in 1986 set off a global search for a collection worth up to $500 million. But after early success, progress has been slow.
item.dc:creator: AMY QIN

item.title: Buoyed by Donald Trump Win, Jerusalem Mayor Hopes to Get U.S. Embassy
item.media:description: Mayor Nir Barkat of Jerusalem says he is optimistic that when Donald J. Trump is president, he will move the United States Embassy from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem, whose status is contested by Israel and the Palestinians.
item.description: Nir Barkat said that in a Trump administration, he expected the embassy to be moved from Tel Aviv “sooner rather than later.”
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Iran and Boeing Sign $16.6 Billion Deal on Sale of 80 Aircraft
item.media:description: A Boeing 747 belonging to Iran’s national airline at Mehrabad International Airport in Tehran in 2003.
item.description: The agreement, to be carried out over 10 years, may face opposition from supporters of President-elect Donald J. Trump in Congress.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Istanbul Journal: In a Smoky Haze, Turks Cling to Their Cigarettes
item.media:description: Smoking outside a cafe in the neighborhood of Kadikoy in Istanbul this month. Turkey’s efforts to impose restrictions and counteract its reputation as a haven for heavy smoking have had little success.
item.media:credit: Tara Todras-Whitehill for The New York Times
item.description: Turkey has made strong efforts to counteract its smoking habit, with measures nearly as strict as those in any Western country. But smokers resist.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND

item.title: Attack on Coptic Cathedral in Cairo Kills Dozens
item.media:description: The attack was the deadliest against Egypt’s Christian minority in years.
item.description: The bombing killed at least 25 people and was the deadliest attack against Egypt’s Christian minority in years.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH and NOUR YOUSSEF
item.category: St Mark's Coptic Orthodox Cathedral (Cairo, Egypt)

item.title: With Uncertainties Roiling Washington and Seoul, What Next for North Korea?
item.media:description: Fireworks illuminated the sky during a rally against South Korea’s president, Park Geun-hye, in Seoul on Saturday.
item.description: South Korea, in the wake of the vote to impeach its president, may choose a new leader who pursues a more open diplomacy with the North.
item.dc:creator: MOTOKO RICH

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: How Xi Jinping Can Avoid Becoming a Dictator
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping of China. No hints of a possible successor have emerged, suggesting that he might seek to extend his tenure.
item.description: The Chinese president’s best option for prolonging his tenure is to overhaul the Communist Party’s system of governance.
item.dc:creator: HO PIN

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Don’t Caricature Europe’s Court
item.media:description: The European Court of Human Rights, in Strasbourg.
item.description: The European Court of Human Rights is a remarkable success in the international rule of law. Demagogues run it down at great risk.
item.dc:creator: THORBJORN JAGLAND

item.title: Editorial: Flawed Choices for the State Department
item.media:description: Rex Tillerson at the World Gas Conference in Paris, in 2015.
item.description: Donald Trump has apparently chosen for the top post an apologist for Russia and for deputy a past diplomat with dangerous policies.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD

item.title: Where Even Nightmares Are Classified: Psychiatric Care at Guantánamo
item.media:description: A guard tower at a now-empty detention block at Guantánamo Bay. The prison, where nearly 800 men were held over the years, now has 60 detainees.
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: Secrecy, mistrust and the shadow of interrogation at the American prison limited doctors’ ability to treat mental illness among detainees.
item.dc:creator: SHERI FINK
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Postcard From the Hajj: A Pilgrim’s Progress: Checking Mecca Off My Bucket List
item.media:description: “Pilgrims surprised me with their warmth.”
item.description: This reporter’s long-dreamed-of journey to explore the heart of Islam revealed surprises, debunked stereotypes and produced one stunning bird video.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: Turkish Dam Project Threatens to Submerge Thousands of Years of History
item.media:description: The Turkish town of Hasankeyf will be submerged under 200 feet of water after a hydroelectric dam now under construction is completed.
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.description: A contentious dam project that dates to the 1950s is more than 80 percent complete, and the filling of a reservoir will swamp much of the town of Hasankeyf.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO

item.title: Devanampattinam Journal: Mortal to Divine and Back: India’s Transgender Goddesses
item.description: During the 10-day Hindu festival Mayana Kollai, the troubles of transgender women are distant as they transform into the deities they worship and are revered by villagers.
item.dc:creator: Photographs by CANDACE FEIT
